# Quantative Data Visualizations ::: {.cell hash='03-quant-vis_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-1_eced539656eab2d6b2fca6fe44156649'} ::: ## Dot Plots Dot plots are for discrete quantitative variables only, and they are only useful in situations when you have a small range of number so that you can actually see how the data distribution varies across values. Dot plots are simple, you draw a number line and then plot points above the number for each of the number that you see in the data. Take this data for example: ::: {.cell hash='03-quant-vis_cache/html/student-table_97558167412fcf7520ac985efeb53ea9'} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ::: Now count up each value to figure out how many dots you need at each value on the number line then plot your graph ::: {.cell hash='03-quant-vis_cache/html/student-dot-plot_00ceab556ddad00233e2978a0590cc90'} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](03-quant-vis_files/figure-html/student-dot-plot-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Stemplots Using this data as an example, ::: {.cell hash='03-quant-vis_cache/html/stemplot-data_50911215c52b15fa77d29831add6b681'} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ::: A stem plot looks like this: ::: {.cell hash='03-quant-vis_cache/html/stemplot-pic_7c14d42a03998c677b9c5a02c4e07b52'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 1 | 2: represents 12 leaf unit: 1 n: 20 0 | 1 1 | 8 2 | 3 | 36689 4 | 4 5 | 2339 6 | 0228 7 | 8 | 19 9 | 35 ``` ::: ::: In a stem plot, you need to determine a common "stem" of all the numbers that you're plotting. So if you have integer numbers from 10 to 200, your stems will be everything from the tens and so on, so you'll have stems from 1-20. Once you take the stems, you just write the "leaves" next to the stem that they belong. Note that you also have to add a key to show what a stem + leaf means. The stem and leaves give no information on the decimals in the data, so as you see above, you need to give an example like (as shown in the example stemplot): Key: 1\|2 = 12 Here's another example (sorted for convenience) ::: {.cell hash='03-quant-vis_cache/html/stemplot-pic-2_b79472e0aa499ebd9c821f6ebc4b332a'} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 1 | 2: represents 1.2 leaf unit: 0.1 n: 50 3 | 3 3 | 579999 4 | 00334 4 | 556677788899 5 | 00112233444 5 | 667888999 6 | 234 6 | 5 7 | 12 ``` ::: ::: ## Boxplots *Also known as a box-and-whisker plot* Boxplots are primarily made of the **five number summary** of the data. The five number summary is made up of the: - Minimum (min) - First Quartile ($Q_1$) - Median - Third Quartile ($Q_3$) - Maximum (max) To make a simple boxplot, you use the first quartile, median, and third quartile to make the "box" and then use the minimum and maximum to make the "whiskers." For this simple list of numbers: ::: {.cell hash='03-quant-vis_cache/html/simple-x_f26d83d44907abd161d0f10ba39451ed'} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ::: Our five number summary is: ::: {.cell hash='03-quant-vis_cache/html/simple-5ns_22f7c1eac2efd242c0b8bebdc3928bd3'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Min. 1st Qu. Median 3rd Qu. Max. 1 2 4 6 7 ``` ::: ::: As detailed above, our box plot then looks like: ::: {.cell hash='03-quant-vis_cache/html/simple-boxplot_4fe2061a057e7d5c6948da73a042214f'} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](03-quant-vis_files/figure-html/simple-boxplot-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: The last detail is that we can calculate outliers using the 1.5 IQR rule and show them on the boxplot. For either direction (left or right), if we see outliers in that direction, we only extend the whisker to the smallest and/or largest point that is not an outlier. Then we plot any outliers as individual points. Look at this example data: ::: {.cell hash='03-quant-vis_cache/html/adv-boxplot-data_78be89df4014fb552d33d7738a385725'} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ::: Five number summary: ::: {.cell hash='03-quant-vis_cache/html/adv-5ns_672d3e22079bea8ebaba54af604253c5'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Min. 1st Qu. Median 3rd Qu. Max. -12 -5 -3 0 12 ``` ::: ::: Our numbers calculated by the 1.5 IQR rule are: ::: {.cell hash='03-quant-vis_cache/html/adv-iqr_16601ae8779786eb319c9a57353f720e'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] -12.5 7.5 ``` ::: ::: So our 12 is an outlier. which means we draw our right whisker to 6 and plot the 12 individually on the number line. Like so: ::: {.cell hash='03-quant-vis_cache/html/Advanced Box Plot_0d13087d7157a185a192e83634c6ca90'} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](03-quant-vis_files/figure-html/Advanced Box Plot-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Histograms A histogram is similar to a [bar plot](#bar-plots), except that histograms are made for quantitative data and *bars are continuous* in the sense that there is no gap between bars. To make a histogram, select an appropriate equal intervals that make it so that you don't have too many bars and that you don't have too few bars. Your goal with histograms, as with many other visualizations, is to be able to see the shape and characteristics of the distribution in question. If you have too many bars or too few bars, you won't be able to see much important information (especially think of situations when you have many data points with very precise decimal measurements). 1. Decide on your intervals (e.g. by 5's, by 10's, by 100's) 2. Within your intervals, count up the number of observations that belong in that "bin". When you do so, count up observations so that you count the left end inclusive and the right end inclusive. So if you did intervals of 5, you would do something like counting up points $0 \leq x < 5$, $5 \leq x < 10$, and so on. 3. Plot your bars. Example: Consider this example data set: ::: {.cell hash='03-quant-vis_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-2_e42058e5e6fcff23892397b471bba060'} ::: Our data has this set of summary statistics: ::: {.cell hash='03-quant-vis_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-3_c002dfcc67b13f2e6c52eaa9006feb01'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` x Min. :1.522 1st Qu.:1.912 Median :2.022 Mean :2.110 3rd Qu.:2.224 Max. :2.704 ``` ::: ::: With this knowledge, let's make our 7 "bins", so let's do these by every 0.2, starting at 1.5 to 2.9. This will be something that you build by intuition. Now, count up our values: ::: {.cell hash='03-quant-vis_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-4_8b7bf1cb9691ba158f19d5003a899e34'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1.5,1.7) [1.7,1.9) [1.9,2.1) [2.1,2.3) [2.3,2.5) [2.5,2.7) [2.7,2.9] 1 4 6 5 1 2 1 ``` ::: ::: Now, we just put it together. For each bin, we have a bar and the bars' heights correspond to the number of individuals in each bin. ::: {.cell hash='03-quant-vis_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-5_a50087b92372e1cbadda458c698c968a'} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](03-quant-vis_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: Again, just like bar graphs, we can instead do the relative frequencies (this is what you'll see most of the time!!!) ::: {.cell hash='03-quant-vis_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-6_806456bfa0faa68aafdcd5e740c9e9d3'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1.5,1.7) [1.7,1.9) [1.9,2.1) [2.1,2.3) [2.3,2.5) [2.5,2.7) [2.7,2.9] 0.05 0.20 0.30 0.25 0.05 0.10 0.05 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell hash='03-quant-vis_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-7_eaa6360c1b1d897469c09d8f99dc727c'} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](03-quant-vis_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: When you have a histogram like this, keep in mind that the bars always add up to 1 (or 100%).
